awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: What are the causes and consequences of reproductive cooperation between unrelated male fish?
awd_abstract_narration:
Interactions between organisms can take a variety of forms, from competition and conflict to cooperation. While cooperation among relatives is both well documented and relatively well understood in everything from slime molds to primates, cooperation among unrelated individuals, especially those that also compete directly with one another, remains more puzzling. The proposed research will study what social and environmental factors cause unrelated male marine fish to either cooperate or compete with one another. This research will also identify the genes, brain regions and hormones that control these behaviors - currently, there is little specific information on these mechanisms - and measure how cooperative versus competitive interactions affect reproduction in this species. Understanding what shapes cooperation, competition and conflict is not only of general interest, but can also inform conservation and management because negative interactions such as conflict and competition have been shown to increase a species risk of extinction. This project supports the training of undergraduate and graduate students on a variety of biological methods including field research on marine fish and tools for understanding the genes underlying social behavior. The professors and students involved in this research will also offer internships to high school students, education outreach lectures and online activities aimed at women and girls interested in science fields and careers. Several involved students will be from an undergraduate-focused institution which draws a number of non-traditional STEM students which will allow these students direct training opportunities that they otherwise would not have access to.

The long-term goal of our research is to understand how social interactions and selection interact to shape variation in reproductive behaviors. We aim to quantify male plasticity in social behavior, document neural and hormonal mechanisms underlying plasticity in male social behavior, and determine how variation in male social interactions affects selection. To address these aims, we propose research on wild-living ocellated wrasse (a marine fish, Symphodus ocellatus). Ocellated wrasse males exhibit three alternative reproductive types: 'nesting males' provide parental care, defend territories, and form cooperative associations with unrelated 'satellites', who cheat by sneaking fertilizations but help by reducing reproductive competition from 'sneakers' (who do not cooperate or provide care; Stiver & Alonzo 2013). We adopt an integrative approach that allows us to examine the reproductive fitness consequences of variation in cooperation and competition and identify neural and hormonal mechanisms underlying this variation and behavioral plasticity.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit 

Analysis of satellite removal data suggests that replacement satellite behavior is indistinguishable from that of the original males within 24 hours. However, half of replacement satellites are unable to maintain their new position. Variation in success in holding position appears to relate to how close a new satellite is permitted to approach the nest, as well as their rate of female following (lower in unstable satellites). Completion of this work is on hold while we investigation video-based methods of satellite size estimation (as half were replaced before we could measure them).

Analysis of nesting male removal data suggests that replacement satellite behavior is indistinguishable from that of the original males within 5 minutes of his establishing himself as the new dominant male. All nesting males held on to their new position; however, the nesting male changeover was followed by satellite loss or turnover at two-thirds of the manipulated nests, suggesting existing subordinate partners' residency is destabilized by nesting male turn-over. This study will be completed and submitted to journals in 2024.

An examination of male type preference for associating with novel objects and females in different scenarios reveals that while there was no difference among types in preference for familiar versus unfamiliar females or objects, satellite males switched between options when assessing females more often than nesting males did. All male types showed a preference for associating with larger rather than smaller groups of females.

Examination of spawn and sneak timing revealed that satellite males have a time-advantage over sneakers in sneak-spawning. Paternity analysis of eggs fertilized in-vitro under different time delay conditions is ongoing to better quantify the impact of such time-delays on fertilization success. 

Preliminary examination of the dynamics of a new satellite filling a vacancy suggests that nesting males de-escalate aggression 10 minutes after loss of their satellite, at which time potential satellites also increase their attempts to bring females to the nest. Behavioral coding and analysis is ongoing. 

Preliminary examination of the role of isotocin in nesting males suggest that isotocin administration is associated with an initial increase then decrease of nesting male aggression, which administration of the antagonist showed no clear impact on behavior. Preliminary results suggest larger (potentially older) satellite males are less cooperative than smaller satellite males. Aging is still needed to verify this suggestion.


 

Broader Impacts:

Southern Connecticut State University is an undergraduate focused institution, composed primarily of first-generation students, and with a high proportion of underrepresented groups in STEM. Since the start of the grant, funding has provided a field research experience for an undergraduate and graduate student, and training in behavioral observation for 5 undergraduate and 3 graduate students from this RUI institution, plus an additional graduate student from Dayton University.. All students hired on this grant are members of one or more marginalized groups under-represented in STEM. Funding has also enabled PI Stiver to “buy-out” of teaching and focus relatively more on research activities and supervision than is typically possible at this institution (SCSU contract specifies a 24-credit per year load, which typically translates to a 4/4 teaching requirement).

Beyond direct research training experiences for students, the date have been used in teaching to expand student understanding of sexual conflict and parental investment, and in K-12 classroom visits to educate students about behavioral ecology research and academic careers.
